channel.title: Cities - Digg
channel.description: Cities on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Why Fewer Cars On The Road Means California Is Saving $40 Million A Day
item.description: It turns out that having 15,000 fewer accidents per month can save the state some cash.

item.title: Meet The Rent Strikers Of The Pandemic Recession
item.description: The rent was due on April 1 and these tenants have no intention of paying it — not now, not ever.

item.title: Watch This Stand-Off In Denver Between A Protester And Healthcare Worker
item.description: To protest the stay-at-home-orders, drivers attempted to clog certain roads in Denver, Colorado, on Sunday.

item.title: Colorado: Images of the Centennial State
item.description: A few glimpses of Colorado's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.
item.kicker: HIGH PLAINS TO THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS

item.title: Hear The Soundscapes Of Cities Transformed
item.description: The sonic landscape has changed. Even in the biggest, most densely populated cities, amid the uncertainty and suffering of the pandemic, people are beginning to hear something entirely new.

item.title: Can You Get A Coronavirus Test? It May Depend On Where You Live
item.description: Five scenarios that show the differences in states' testing algorithms.

item.title: A Construction Mistake In Rome That Created A Lake And United A Neighborhood
item.description: With no local government able to take control of the situation, an accidental lake became the unexpected catalyst of a community struggle for new ecological and urban imaginations.

item.title: Pandemics Have Destroyed Cities Before. Could They Do It Again?
item.description: Charles Kenny, author of a forthcoming book on pandemics, is cautiously optimistic that cities will prevail in the era of COVID-19 — but nothing is a given.

item.title: We Called Unemployment Offices In All 50 States. Only Two Picked Up
item.description: Just like everyone else, we found reaching a human being to be next to impossible right now.

item.title: How To Make A City Livable During Lockdown
item.description: From wider sidewalks to better balconies: tips from a long-time urbanist.

item.title: The Pandemic Could Be An Opportunity To Remake Cities
item.description: Cities from Bogota to Oakland are closing streets to make room for pedestrians and bikers. Urbanists think we'd be healthier if such changes were permanent.

item.title: The Power Of Parks In A Pandemic
item.description: For city residents, equitable access to local green space is more than a coronavirus-era amenity. It's critical for physical, emotional and mental health.

item.title: In The Pandemic, Squatters Are Reclaiming Homes For The Families Who Need Them
item.description: In LA alone, 46,000 housing units sit completely vacant. "The Reclaimers" believe these empty dwellings could be the key to ending housing insecurity in the city.

item.title: Closing The Parks Is Ineffective Pandemic Theater
item.description: Public green spaces are good for the immune system and the mind — and they can be rationed to allow for social distancing.

item.title: The Fascinating History Behind How London Split Up Into 32 Boroughs
item.description: Jay Foreman gives the intriguing backstory on how the current boroughs of London got delineated.
item.kicker: THE EAST END BOYS AND WEST END GIRLS

item.title: The Post-Pandemic Urban Future Is Already Here
item.description: The coronavirus crisis stands to dramatically reshape cities around the world. But the biggest revolutions in urban space may have begun before the pandemic.

item.title: Visualizing The Footprint Of Highways In American Cities
item.description: Highways improved mobility for the average American, ingraining the automobile into the urban fabric of American cities — for better and worse.
item.kicker: SHOW ME THE WAY TO GO HOME

item.title: There Is No Plan For The End Of The Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: On top of Trump's ongoing mismanagement, there is a shocking lack of a strategy, or discussion of a strategy, at any level of government, for what the country will do after the current wave of coronavirus cases passes.

item.title: Mumbai Looks Eerie From Above After The City Was Locked Down Over The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Mumbai Live got permission from the government to take a video of Mumbai from a drone — here is the scene on the ground.

item.title: In An Alaska Town Where Almost Everyone Lives Under The Same Roof, The Pandemic Threat Feels Different
item.description: About 80% of the residents of Whittier live in a single high-rise apartment building.

item.title: Florida Sheriff Is Here to Debunk Your 'Tiger King' Cold-Case Theories
item.description: Hillsborough County Sheriff Chad Chronister spoke to us about the Netflix documentary series "Tiger King," Joe Exotic, Carole Baskin, Don Lewis and the open murder case.
item.kicker: ANYTHING GOES IN BIG CAT LAND

item.title: The Coronavirus Is Washing Over The US. These Factors Will Determine How Bad It Gets In Each Community
item.description: As the coronavirus outbreak rolls across the country, residents are asking: Who will be hit next? And how fast and how hard?

item.title: The Problem With A Coronavirus Rent Strike
item.description: Because of coronavirus, millions of tenants won't be able to write rent checks. But calls for a rent holiday often ignore the longer-term economic effects.
item.kicker: CONVINCE MAUREEN TO CANCEL HER PROTEST

item.title: Sneezeguards, Toilet Paper, And Visits From Lonely Seniors: Running A Post Office During The Pandemic
item.description: More people than ever are shopping online — and to meet their needs, postal workers are taking big risks.

item.title: The Green Dream Of Portland
item.description: Decades ago, Portland, Oregon established an image as the most environmentally friendly city in the world. But is the progressive city's progress still too slow?

item.title: Coronavirus Will Hit Small Towns Hard As People Leave Cities
item.description: You might not want to spend your quarantine in a city. But the rural places many Americans treat as playgrounds, and the workers who keep them running, will suffer for it.

item.title: What The Largest Cities In America Look Like During The Coronavirus Pandemic From The Sky
item.description: Spooky aerial views of the empty cityscapes of the American metropolises under quarantine.

item.title: How Long Are We Going To Be Stuck Like This?
item.description: The coronavirus has left millions of people in limbo. Experts believe it will be weeks or months before things get back to normal. How will we know it's safe to go on with our lives again?
item.kicker: AND I THINK IT'S GONNA BE A LONG, LONG TIME

item.title: This Footage Of A Completely Empty New York City Is Unbelievably Eerie
item.description: The music choice (Mozart's mournful "Requiem in D Minor") lends an extra edge, but the clips of a locked down Manhattan are unsettling on their own.

item.title: North Dakota: Images Of The Peace Garden State
item.description: A few glimpses of North Dakota's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.

item.title: The NIMBYs Of The Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: Why would residents block a COVID-19 testing site? For the same reason many oppose other forms of neighborhood change: a desire to shift the burden elsewhere.

item.title: The Ethical Failures Of Modern Architecture
item.description: Why do famous architects continue to work with corrupt authoritarians and pernicious corporations?

item.title: As Disasters Mount, Our Cities May Need To Move Underground
item.description: Temperatures are rising and urban centers are packed. To preserve livable societies, some argue we should build "Earthscrapers."

item.title: Self-Isolation In A Small Town
item.description: The coronavirus has slowed down the pace of human activity in cities. In a small college town, the sudden stillness is not so severe. But the pace of felt change has accelerated, resulting in a similarly disorienting effect.

item.title: Inside One Man's Mission To Treat LA's Homeless For COVID-19
item.description: The homeless in America's cities are at high risk for COVID-19 — which, in turn, increases the risk for everyone. Brett Feldman is on the front lines trying to help.

item.title: The People Leading When Leaders Do Not
item.description: Business owners, pastors and others are voluntarily closing their doors as the coronavirus spreads, seeking to fill a void when clarity from political leaders is lacking.

item.title: Where Did Los Angeles Get Its Retrofuturistic Architecture Style From?
item.description: Take a drive around Los Angeles and you'll see a lot of buildings with sharp angles and kitschy neon lights. Douglas Haskell named it "Googie architecture" and the name stuck. How did the style take off?

item.title: What A Coronavirus Recovery Could Look Like
item.description: Urban resilience expert Michael Berkowitz shares ideas about how US cities can come back stronger from the social and economic disruption of coronavirus.

item.title: The Surprising Things The Coronavirus Shutdown Is Revealing About Traffic
item.description: The bright side is what traffic experts — and drivers — can learn about improving the commute experience in the future.

item.title: Local Responses To The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: In the past two weeks, Americans have already seen governors and mayors, schools and hospitals, religious organizations and foundations and nonprofit groups taking the lead while the national government has faltered.

item.title: The Strange, Fragile Normalcy Of Life In Singapore
item.description: Hailed for its early efforts to contain Covid-19, Singapore has recently seen a surge in new coronavirus cases. Still, daily life is surprisingly unaffected.

item.title: What San Francisco Looks Like Now After The Shelter In Place Order
item.description: San Francisco looks like a scene from "I Am Legend" right now.

item.title: This Graffiti-Covered Abandoned Highway In Pennsylvania Looks Like A Scene From A Horror Movie
item.description: There's something eerily beautiful about abandoned places — they look surprisingly calm yet still manage to make you feel as if someone's watching you.

item.title: An Intersection At The End Of America
item.description: A portrait of Dilley, Texas, home of the largest immigration detention center in the United States.

item.title: Rome Looks Like A Post-Apocalyptic Wasteland Right Now
item.description: Gone are the tourists. Gone are the Vespas. The cityscape of Rome is completely unrecognizable during Italy's coronavirus crisis.

item.title: The Lockout: Why Uber Drivers In NYC Are Sleeping In Their Cars
item.description: Uber and Lyft's response to pay floor regulations was an algorithmic quota system that has become a dystopic rat race.

item.title: I Photographed The Surreal Week Coronavirus Gripped My City
item.description: Two weeks ago Prague was thronged with tourists and businesses were humming as the city headed into a long-awaited spring. Today the lanes and famous squares of my adopted town stand virtually empty.

item.title: How Real Architecture Inspired The Futuristic Cities Of 'Westworld'
item.description: The deluxe urban dystopia in "Westworld" season three, agleam with prosperity and gentrified to a high polish, is the latest in a long line of meticulously fantasized cityscapes of tomorrow.

item.title: A Day In The Life Of A Delivery Guy During Coronavirus Panic
item.description: "I thought I'd be getting fat-ass tips. I'm not getting fat-ass tips."

item.title: How Helsinki And Oslo Cut Pedestrian Deaths To Zero
item.description: After years of committed action, neither city recorded a single pedestrian fatality in 2019.
